trope_detail: Spock entertained by vibrating flowers. He even smiles.
Spock screams when the men are left on the Enterprise and Number One and Yeoman Colt are transported to Talos IV.
Spock: Fascinating. | McCoy: So improbable we almost didn't check it. |  (after finding a total lack of sodium chloride in Sturgeons body.).

Uhura: Tell me how your planet Vulcan looks on a lazy evening when the moon is full. | Spock: Vulcan has no moon, Miss Uhura. | Uhura: I'm not surprised, Mr. Spock. | Spock gives Uhura a raised eyebrow.
McCoy: He's dead Jim. (after examining  Sturgeons body).
Spock: A very interesting hypothesis, Doctor. Briefing room.
Spock gets over-emotional when reporting the ship's status.
Uhura: There's something off the starboard bow.
Spock jokes about those earth emotions  then laughs.
ep_title: Where No Man Has Gone Before

trope_detail: Spock shouts commands in an overly excited voice.
ep_title: Where No Man Has Gone Before

trope_detail: Spock breaks down crying after being infected by Psi 2000 virus.
Scotty: I can't change the laws of physics.

Spock: Fascinating. A pattern is developing. First, Tormolen. Hidden personality traits being forced to the surface. Then Riley, who fancies himself a descendant of Irish kings, and now Sulu, who is at heart a swashbuckler out of your 18th century.
Nurse Chapel: He's dead doctor.
McCoy: He's dead Jim.
Spock: The, er, impostor had some interesting qualities, wouldn't you, say, Yeoman?
Spock uses sarcasm then wears a shit eating grin.
Spock does a lengthy explanation on how the transporter got fixed. Bla bla blaâ€¦
Ruth Bonavure: Its fascinating. (Ruth steps in front of medical scanner which goes crazy befuddling McCoy.).
Spock and Scotty discuss lack of dilithium crystals and the urgency to obtain them from the miners.

Harry Mudd (to Spock): You're part Vulcanian, aren't you. Ah well then, a pretty face doesn't affect you at all, does it. That is, unless you want it to. You can save it, girls. This type can turn himself off from any emotion.
Kirk: I'm tired of your half-breed interference Kirk (thinks this while in duplication machine to put a defect into the android double).
ep_title: What Are Little Girls Made Of?

trope_detail: Kirk-android insults Spock with half-breed comment Kirk instilled in it.
ep_title: What Are Little Girls Made Of?

trope_detail: Spock kids with around with Yeoman Rand and smiles.

Kirk: What's so fascinating? | Spock: An identification tape from our ship's library on Doctor Simon Van Gelder. | Kirk: Doctor Van Gelder? | Spock: Doctor Van Gelder, Captain. No mistake. There's a full ID tape on him. | Kirk: Committed to Tantalus colony when? | Spock: Assigned there six months ago as Doctor Adams' associate.
Spock: Interesting. Your Earth people glorify organized violence for forty centuries, but you imprison those who employ it privately.
Spock mind melds with Dr. Van Gelder to see into his troubled mind.
Spock: Fascinating. | Kirk: What's its mass, Mister Spock? | Spock: Reading goes off my scale, Captain. Must be a mile in diameter.
McCoy: What am I? A doctor or a moon shuttle conductor.
Spock: Might be interesting to see what they look like if I can locate where that voice is coming from. (McCoy and Scotty enter)
Spock stole the Enterprise to return Pike to Talos IV.
First time Spock sees a Romulan he raises an eyebrow.
Spock: Disappeared. Interesting how they became visible for just a moment.
Spock: A place (Amusement Park) where people could go and see all sorts of fascinating things.
Yeoman Barrows (after McCoy skewered by knight): He's dead.
Spock: James Kirk. Enjoy yourself, Captain. It's an interesting planet.
Lt. Bowman: I'm sick and tired of this machine.
Spock considering his options on how to get the Galileo Seven back into space.
Spock accused of desperation move for burning the fuel to use as a flare.
Kirk: Does your logic find this fascinating?  | Spock: Fascinating I use for the unexpected. In this case, interesting should suffice.
Spock tries to classify Trelane to Kirk after their adventure for his report.

McCoy: There's that magic word again. Does your logic find this fascinating, Mister Spock? | Spock: Fascinating is a word I use for the unexpected. In this case, I should think interesting would suffice.
Spock: Fascinating. Good. Good. He knows, Doctor. He has reasoned it out.
Spock sworn in as Vulcanian.
Spock (examining minion of Landru weapon): Fascinating. This is merely a hollow tube.

Spock: We shouldn't depend on that happening again, Captain. In a society as well organized as this one seems to be, I cannot conceive of such an oversight going uncorrected. Interesting, however. Their reaction to your defiance was remarkably similar to the reaction of a computer when fed insufficient or contradictory data.
Spock mind melds with McCoy after McCoy was conditioned by Landru.
Spock irritated by Kirks illogical chess play. Raises an eyebrow at Kirk's last move.
Spock: It would be interesting, Captain, to return to that world in a hundred years and to learn what crop has sprung from the seed you planted today.
Spock listens to Anan 7 about how clean a war with computers is. Spock gives him an eyebrow.
McCoy: I'm a doctor, if I was an officer of the lineâ€¦.
Spock mind melds the Eminiar guard through the wall. Makes him open the door.
McCoy: Telepathic abilities are inherent in Vulcanians.
Kirk explains to Spock why they both can't go to the brig. There would be no one to run the ship and save the crew.
Kirk explains to Spock why they both can't go to the brig. There would be no one to run the ship and save the crew.
McCoy figures out how to destroy spores on a worldwide basis without harming any of the people.
Elias: You've know the Vulcanian?
Spock examines silicon nodule. Kirk: You seem fascinated by this rock.
Spock: Fascinating. (while observing Horta).
Spock studies the silicon nodules from the mine and asks Chief Vanderberg about them.
Spock upon his first glance of the Horta.
McCoy: I'm a doctor, not a bricklayer. (when Kirk order McCoy to examine the Horta).

Kirk: Mister Spock? Find something? | Spock: Adjusting my tricorder to register for silicon, Captain. Interesting. | Kirk: Traces? | Spock: A life form, Captain. Bearing one hundred eleven degrees, elevation four degrees.
Spock Mind Melds with Horta in order to talk with it.
Spock wants security to attempt to capture the creature if possible. | Kirk: Your orders are shoot to kill.
Spock: Fascinating, pure energy.

Kor the Klingon: It's a mind-sifter or mind-ripper, depending on how much force is used. We can record every thought, every bit of knowledge in a man's mind. Of course, when that much force is used, the mind is emptied. Permanently, I'm afraid. What's left is more vegetable than human. Spock gives him the eyebrow.
Spock raises an eyebrow after , Kirk says: We didn't beat the odds. The Organians raided the game.
Kirk: I'm a soldier, not a diplomat.
Kirk: Are you sure you're all right? | Spock: Perfectly, Baroner. But it was an interesting experience.
Klingon: He claims to be a Vulcanian merchant.
Spock: Fascinating. In regards to Guardian.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: Spock when talking to the guardian.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: Spock's rasies an eyebrow to Kirk: It would pose an extremely complex problem in logic Mr. Spock.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: Spock's response to Kirk: Sometimes I expect too much of you.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: Spock's response when the Guardian calls Spock's science knowledge primitive.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: McCoy: I'm a surgeon, not a psychiatrist.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: Edith: You know as well as I do how out of place you two are around here. | Spock: Interesting. Where would you estimate we belong, Miss Keeler? | Edith: You? At his side, as if you've always been there and always will. And you? You belong in another place. I don't know where or how. I'll figure it out eventually.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: Kirk: Well, Mister Spock, if we can't disguise you, we'll find some way of explaining you. Spock: That should prove interesting.
ep_title: The City on the Edge of Forever

trope_detail: McCoy: Please don't tell Spock I said he was the best first officer in the fleet. | Spock: Why, thank you, Doctor McCoy.
Spock's response to McCoy as he examines him after parasite stung him.

Spock: Come in, gentlemen. I believe you'll find this interesting. (McCoy scans Spock.) Doctor, your medical skill and curiosity are quite admirable, but I assure you I'm all right. | McCoy: You may be controlling the pain, Mister Spock, but you're far from all right. | Spock: Unimportant at the moment, Doctor. Please observe. Interesting, gentlemen. A one-celled creature resembling, more than anything else, a huge, individual brain cell.
Spock: Interesting. Just as dogs are sensitive to certain sounds which humans cannot hear, these creatures evidently are sensitive to light which we cannot see.

trope: Not Life As We Know It
trope_detail: Spock: Its not life as we know or understand it. (explaining how these aliens were single cells of a larger organism).
Spock, after seeing Kirk alive, has an emotional outburst. Spock raises an eyebrow at Kirk and McCoy and goes back to being stoic.
McCoy: He's dead. (says after Kirk & Spock fight).

McCoy: Spock, what happened down there? The girl? The wedding? | Spock: Ah, yes, the girl. Most interesting. It must have been the combat. When I thought I had killed the captain, I found I had lost all interest in T'Pring. The madness was gone.
Spock: live long and prosper.
T'Pau: live long and prosper. | Spock: I shall do neither.
Spock and T'Pau mind meld before the battle.
Spock gets crazy when Nurse Chapel brings soup.
Spock screams when he sees Kirk alive after (apparently) killing him.
Spock and T'Pau exchange the Vulcan salute. (1)
Spock and T'Pau exchange the Vulcan salute. (2)
Chekov has a phaser. He attempts to fire it but its unfunctional.
McCoy: To coin a phrase, fascinating.
Chekov claims Alice in Wonderland is a Russian story.
Chekov: Just like Russia | McCoy:  More like the Garden of Eden. | Chekov: The Garden of Eden was just outside Moscow.
Spock: Fascinating Captain.
Spock calculates the size of Nomad realizing how tiny the object was. Spock raises an eyebrow.
Spock raises an eyebrow when Nomad brings Scotty back to life.

Spock's response to Kirk: Well, it thought I was its mother, didn't it? Do you think I'm completely without feelings, Mister Spock? You saw what it did for Scotty. What a doctor it would've made. My son, the doctor. Kind of gets you right there, doesn't it?
Spock's silent reaction to McCoy as they follow Kirk and Nomad out of the transporter room.
McCoy: He's dead Jim. (after Nomad kills him.)
Spock mind melds with Nomad. Learns much of 'the other' but Nomad won't let go of his mind till commanded by Kirk.
Chekov gets his own torture scene with lots of yelling and screaming.
Kirk: What is it that will buy you? | Spock: Fascinating. (when Mirror Kirk tries to bribe Spock to release them.)
Kirk (to Spock about Mirror Kirk returning): That Jim Kirk will find a few changes if I read my Spock's correctly.
Mirror Spock's raises an eyebrow after Kirk says he has a device which will make Spock invincible in his attempt to correct the direction of the Empire.
McCoy: I'm a Doctor, not an Engineer.
Spock: Apparently some kind of transposition has taken place. I find it extremely interesting.
Mirror Spock mind melds with McCoy to find out Kirks real intent.
Chekov has a phaser. Never fires it.
Spock: Captain, This is fascinating. (about Akuta's antenna).
Spock: Fascinating. (as they walk into Vaal's cave.)

Spock: Precisely, Captain, and in a manner of speaking, we have given the people of Vaal the apple, the knowledge of good and evil if you will, as a result of which they too have been driven out of paradise. | Kirk: Doctor, do I understand him correctly? Are you casting me in the role of Satan? | Spock: Not at all, Captain. | Kirk: Is there anyone on this ship who even remotely looks like Satan? (McCoy and Kirk walk around Spock. McCoy is gazing intently at his ears.) | Spock: I am not aware of anyone who fits that description, Captain. | Kirk: No, Mister Spock. I didn't think you would be.

Spock: Interesting. Extremely low specific gravity, some uraninite, hornblende, quartz. (breaks it in half) Fragile, good cleavage. An analysis should prove interesting. (He throws one half away, and it explodes when it hits the ground.)
Spock: I wonder if there are any more of those weapons wandering around the universe. | Kirk: I certainly hope not. I found one quite sufficient.

Spock: We have given the people of Vaal the apple, if you will, they too have been driven out of paradise. | Kirk: Are you casting me in the role of Satan? | Spock: Not at all, Captain. | Kirk: Is there anyone on this ship who even remotely looks like Satan? | Spock: I am not aware of anyone who fits that description, Captain. | Kirk: No, Mister Spock. I didn't think you would be.
Kirk: Did you ever hear of the Doomsday Machine? | McCoy: I'm a Doctor, not an Mechanic.
Kirk: Their forms were an Illusion. Only the power pack gave them reality. | Spock: Fascinating.
Spock (as Kirk, Spock, and Korob encounter Sylvia as a giant cat): Fascinating
McCoy: The man is dead.
Spock: Fascinating (after putting two Alice's out of commission with the I love you, but I hate you cause you're identical logic bomb.)
Spock: Fascinating (after the encounter with Alice 471 where she's confused about unhappiness.)
McCoy: He's dead (after Kirk and co pull prank on Norman attempting to escape android world.)
Norman: I trust you are enjoying yourself, Mister Spock. | Spock: Very interesting. Very interesting. This is a most unusual device. | Norman: It is our central control complex.
Spock mind melds with Norman the Android. Finds Norman has turned himself off.
Spock (after waking up from the Companions shock): A most fascinating thing happened doctor. Apparently the Companion imparted to me a rather quaint, old-fashioned electric shock.
Zefrem Cochrane storms out when he finds out the Companion loves him. | Spock: Fascinating. A totally parochial attitude.
Spock: Fascinating (as Cochrane appears n the distance)Then Spock raises an eyebrow.

Amanda: Nothing is as important as your father's life | Spock: can you imagine what my father would say if I were to agree , if I were to give up command of this vessel,. Jeopardize hundreds of lives , risk interplanetary war, all for the life of one person.
Spock gives an eyebrow to Sarek as Sarek rebuffs him for not attending the Vulcan Science Academy
Chekov: Phasers armed and ready, sir. (The bright dot on the view screen whizzes past them.) | Spock: Interesting. They were travelling at approximately warp ten.

Kirk: Spock. A short time ago, I broke up an argument between Gav and your father. | Spock: Indeed, Captain? Interesting. | McCoy: Interesting? Spock, do you realize that makes your father the most likely suspect?
Sarek gives Vulcan salute to Kirk
Sarek gives Vulcan salute to McCoy
Spock gives Vulcan salute to Sarek. Sarek ignores him.
Spock shows McCoy how to do the Vulcan salute
McCoy: I'm a doctor, not an escalator.
Scotty: There's an old saying. Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me. | Chekov: I know this saying. It was invented in Russia.
Eleen: McCoy. Bring our child. | Kirk: Our child? | McCoy: I'll explain later. | Spock: That should prove very interesting.

Kirk: An obscure Earth dialect, Mister Spock. Oochy-woochy coochy-coo. If you're curious, consult linguistics. | Spock: Well, at any rate, this should prove interesting. | Kirk: Interesting? |Spock: When the woman starts explaining how the new high teer is actually Doctor McCoy's child.
Chekov: Blood sample, Chekov! Marrow sample, Chekov! Skin sample, Chekov! If â€“ if I live long enough, I'm going to run out of samples!.
Spock: Concerning the situation you related to us. In my opinion, the Argelian empathic contact is an interesting phenomenon, but the technique is not sound enough to risk a man's life.

HAINES: (A woman in gold uniform at Spock's station) Mister Spock, I'm getting a fluctuating energy reading on this hydrogen cloud. It's faint, sir, but it consistently reads an excess of predictable energy level. | Spock: Interesting. It seems to be an ionization trail.
McCoy: Well we're not going to leave them there while we just sit and wait. | Spock: Interesting. No power source. It may be shielded.
Kirk: Key in the ignition. Turn the ignition on. And nothing happens. Where's the starter? There's the starter. Yes! | Spock: Interesting.

McCoy: They must have interfered with the normal evolution of the planet. | Spock: It will be interesting to see the results of the contamination. | Kirk: We don't know there is contamination. The evidence is only circumstantial.
Spock: Interesting, Captain. Passers-by are carrying, I believe, firearms. (They are approached by two men in neat suits with machine guns.)

UHURA: Captain. There was a message from Starbase Six. Heavy interference. All I get is Intrepid and what sounded like a sector co-ordinate. | Spock: Interesting. No indications of magnetic storms in this sector.

Kirk: Maybe they had help. Maximum orbit. Take us out of range of their detection range. | Spock: Most interesting. We were attacked by a thermonuclear missile from a planet which should have no such weapon.
Spock: The Ekosians are humanoid, so there is apt to be a similarity in architecture. Interesting.
(Spock and Rojan are playing 3D chess.) Spock: Yes. Humans are very peculiar. I often find them unfathomable, but an interesting psychological study.
Spock: Interesting. A neural field?
Spock: Interesting that the villagers know about phasers.

McCoy: I was just trying to make conversation, Spock. | Spock: It would be most interesting to impress your memory engrams on a computer, Doctor. The resulting torrential flood of illogic would be most entertaining.
McCoy: Please, Spock, do me a favor and don't say it's fascinating. | Spock: No. But it is interesting. (McCoy rolls his eyes.)

MERIK: There's been no war here for over four hundred years, Jim. Could, let's say, your land of that same era make that same boast? I think you can see why they don't want to have their stability contaminated by dangerous ideas of other ways and other places. | Spock: Interesting, and given a conservative empire, quite understandable.
Spock: (brings over a magazine) Captain, I thought you might find this interesting.
Spock: Captain, we could say that Mister Seven and Miss Lincoln have some interesting experiences in store for them.
Spock: There is another portion, Captain, which I believe you'll find particularly interesting.

Chekov: Course of asteroid, I mean spaceship two four one mark one seven. | Spock: Interesting. | Kirk: Yes?  Spock: The course Ensign Chekov just gave for the asteroid would put it on a collision course with Daran Five.
ep_title: For the World Is Hollow and I Have Touched the Sky

trope_detail: Marta: No, you mustn't stop me. He's my lover and I have to kill him. (Spock neck-pinches her.) | Spock: She seems to have worked out an infallible method for assuring permanent male fidelity. Interesting.

Spock: I find it mildly interesting and somewhat nostalgic, if I understand the use of that word. | Garth: Nostalgic? | Spock: Yes. It is somewhat reminiscent of the dances that Vulcan children do in nursery school. Of course, the children are not so well co-ordinated.

Scotty: Well, it's fused, all right, but it would take all the power of our main phaser banks to do it. | Spock: Interesting. Scotty: I find nothing interesting in the fact that we're about to blow up. | Spock: No, but the method is fascinating.
Spock [on monitor]: Most interesting. Our host appears to wish us to linger, yet he is apprehensive. It is logical to assume that we are being monitored and that he is aware of our every move.
Spock: Interesting. Obviously, Mister Flint is not yet ready for us to depart.

Spock: Stratos, Captain. A city actually floating in the sky. | Kirk: Looks as tranquil as its reputation, doesn't it. | Spock: It is one of the most interesting metropolises in the galaxy. Have you ever visited here, Captain?
Spock: ???
